page.title: 04Farming near Bisbrooke
page.content:
A crop survey revealed the following information about the agriculture east of Bisbrooke and north of Seaton:
The most common crop is wheat with only a scatteed amount of Barley. There was little oil seed rape or potatoes growing there. All the fields had hedges growing round them, but no fences or walls were in evidence. The farmers grow several fields of grass which are cut for hay. There are only two fields which cattle use for rough grazing. The number of cattle in fields is about 30, being a mixture of bullocks and cows. Near a gateway there is a massive manure heap. In one farm building there is a store of hay and straw bales. Arable fields are about 200x400m2, pastures 100x600m2.
